entity.name: `array.toSorted()`
entity.description: Sort without mutating the original array.
entity.descriptionHtml: Sort without mutating the original array.
entity.descriptionClean: Sort without mutating the original array.

example.codeHighlighted: const values = [1, 10, 21, 2]; const sortedValues = values.toSorted((a, b) => a - b); console.log(sortedValues); // [1, 2, 10, 21] console.log(values); // [1, 10, 21, 2]

webFeature.description_html: The toReversed(), toSorted(), toSpliced(), and with() methods of arrays and typed arrays return changed copies of arrays. They stand in contrast to methods such as sort() or reverse() that change arrays in place.
webFeature.name: Array by copy

example.codeHighlighted: const inventory = [ { name: "bananas", quantity: 0 }, { name: "fish", quantity: 1 }, { name: "cherries", quantity: 5 }, ]; console.log(inventory.findLast(item => item.quantity <2)); // { name: "fish", quantity: 1 }

webFeature.description_html: The findLast() and findLastIndex() methods of arrays and typed arrays search an array in reverse order for the first item that satisfies a test function.
webFeature.name: Array findLast() and findLastIndex()

entity.name: `array.toReversed()`
entity.description: Reverse without mutating the original array.
entity.descriptionHtml: Reverse without mutating the original array.
entity.descriptionClean: Reverse without mutating the original array.

example.codeHighlighted: const items = [1, 2, 3]; const reversedItems = items.toReversed(); console.log(reversedItems); // [3, 2, 1] console.log(items); // [1, 2, 3]

webFeature.description_html: The toReversed(), toSorted(), toSpliced(), and with() methods of arrays and typed arrays return changed copies of arrays. They stand in contrast to methods such as sort() or reverse() that change arrays in place.
webFeature.name: Array by copy

entity.name: `array.toSpliced()`
entity.description: Splice without mutating the original array.
entity.descriptionHtml: Splice without mutating the original array.
entity.descriptionClean: Splice without mutating the original array.

example.codeHighlighted: const months = ["Jan", "Mar", "Apr", "May"]; // Inserting an element at index 1 const months2 = months.toSpliced(1, 0, "Feb");

webFeature.description_html: The toReversed(), toSorted(), toSpliced(), and with() methods of arrays and typed arrays return changed copies of arrays. They stand in contrast to methods such as sort() or reverse() that change arrays in place.
webFeature.name: Array by copy

entity.name: `array.with()`
entity.description: Returns a new array with the element at the given index replaced with the given value.
entity.descriptionHtml: Returns a new array with the element at the given index replaced with the given value.
entity.descriptionClean: Returns a new array with the element at the given index replaced with the given value.

example.codeHighlighted: const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; console.log(arr.with(2, 6)); // [1, 2, 6, 4, 5]

webFeature.description_html: The toReversed(), toSorted(), toSpliced(), and with() methods of arrays and typed arrays return changed copies of arrays. They stand in contrast to methods such as sort() or reverse() that change arrays in place.
webFeature.name: Array by copy

entity.name: `array.fromAsync()`
entity.description: Similar to Array.from but for async iterators.
entity.descriptionHtml: Similar to Array.from but for async iterators.
entity.descriptionClean: Similar to Array.from but for async iterators.

example.codeHighlighted: const asyncIterable = (async function* () { for (let i = 0; i < 5; i++) { await new Promise((resolve) => setTimeout(resolve, 10 * i)); yield i; } })(); Array.fromAsync(asyncIterable).then((array) => console.log(array)); // [0, 1, 2, 3, 4]

webFeature.description_html: The Array.fromAsync() static method copies items from an async iterable object to make a new array.
webFeature.name: Array.fromAsync()
